meaning_mnemonic: This word means <vocabulary>to climb</vocabulary>. You can tell this word is a verb because it ends with an う sound (る, in this case). Its meaning is similar to the meaning of the 上 kanji, which is "above." So this word is all about moving "above" something (in other words, climbing!)
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

土 generally refers to <vocabulary>dirt</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>soil</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>earth</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
I spent all <kanji>evening</kanji> in <reading>be</reading>(べ)d  <vocabulary>last night</vocabulary>. It was a really chill <vocabulary>evening</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>woman</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is a <vocabulary>girl</vocabulary>.

This word has two kanji with hiragana stuck in the middle. That hiragana is the particle の. This time, it just means the noun before の is modifying the noun after it.

女の子 is a casual word for young girls, like kids or teenagers. Sometimes it can also refer to adult women, but only to playfully or affectionately highlight their youthful or girlish qualities.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>woman</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>girl</vocabulary>!

女子 is a relatively formal word commonly used in contexts where classification or categorization by gender is used, such as in sports or school settings.

This kanji has hiragana attached and ends with an い sound. That means it's probably an adjective (and it is!). So, if you take the kanji 小 and its meaning (small), you can figure out the adjective version of it. What is the adjective version of "small?" Actually, it's the same thing: <vocabulary>small</vocabulary>.
This vocab word and the kanji that makes it have the same meaning: <vocabulary>Circle</vocabulary>.

With an い on the end, you can guess that this word is an い-adjective. What is the adjective version of the kanji <kanji>丸</kanji>? "Circle" becomes <vocabulary>circular</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>spherical</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>round</vocabulary>. This, compared to another similar word (円), is more general purpose and can be used with 3D spherical objects as well.

Although this word consists of one kanji that is all alone, it doesn't share its meaning with the parent kanji. But the meanings are similar in a way. This word means <vocabulary>years old</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>age</vocabulary>. With more years comes more <kanji>talent</kanji>, right? That's why this word means "years old" and not "talent," like the parent kanji.

You can stick this word onto numbers to say how old someone is!

Special note for all of you advanced learners out there. When discussing age, 〜歳 is the original and correct kanji to use. Because 〜才 is easier to write and has the same reading, it became mainstream. You'll see it used in writing today, especially in elementary schools. In formal writing though, you'll always want to use 〜歳, which you'll learn later on.
When the <kanji>middle</kanji> kanji is used as a word, it means <vocabulary>inside</vocabulary>. When you're in the middle of something, it means you're <vocabulary>in</vocabulary> that thing!

The 々 symbol just repeats the kanji that comes before it. In other words, 中々 is the same as 中中. Easy! So with 中々, you have <kanji>middle</kanji> x2. When something is more middle than middle itself, it's <vocabulary>rather</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>fairly</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>quite</vocabulary> something. Why? I guess because those are all good middle-level intensifiers.

中々 can be used in positive or negative ways. In a positive way, it usually means something is better than expected, like 中々おいしい (quite delicious). But it's really versatile and could also mean "a little," "very," or "completely" depending on the situation. It might even sound condescending, so be careful how you use it! In a negative sense, you can use it when something is more difficult than expected, like in 中々できない (can't be done easily).

The moon kanji also represents a month, so when you have five of these months, what month of the year is it? That would be <vocabulary>May</vocabulary>, the greatest month of the year (because it has towel day in it!).
<vocabulary>Day five</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>fifth day</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
What happens when you have ten five times? You get <vocabulary>fifty</vocabulary>!
From previous number + つ words, you can probably guess that this word means <vocabulary>five things</vocabulary>.
This vocab is made from a single kanji, which means it shares the same meaning as the parent kanji: <vocabulary>Five</vocabulary>.
Any number with a つ attached to it means you are counting that number of things. In this case, it's <vocabulary>six things</vocabulary>.
Since the kanji 月 means both "moon" and "month," what is the sixth month of the year? January, February, March, April, May, <vocabulary>June</vocabulary>!
It's the kanji for six and day. Put them together and you have the <vocabulary>sixth day</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>day six</vocabulary>).
You have ten and six (not to be confused with six tens!). When you have ten and six, you have a total of <vocabulary>sixteen</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A thousand of these yen things makes this word <vocabulary>one thousand yen</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are… almost the same. The kanji means <kanji>heaven</kanji>, but this word is more about the <vocabulary>heavens</vocabulary>. You know, the great heavens that stretch out high above us?

天 can sometimes refer to religious kinds of heaven (that place we all want to end up someday), but more often it's about the sky and what lies beyond it, so you might also call it the <vocabulary>firmament</vocabulary>.
If <kanji>heaven</kanji> has given you <kanji>talent</kanji>, you must be a <vocabulary>genius</vocabulary>.
The kanji means <kanji>hand</kanji>, and the word means <vocabulary>hand</vocabulary> too! It can also be used to refer to your whole <vocabulary>arm</vocabulary>.

Think of someone holding out their hand at shoulder level. Anything above that equals "skillful." Everything <kanji>below</kanji> that <kanji>hand</kanji> equals <vocabulary>unskillful</vocabulary>. That's why "below hand" means <vocabulary>unskilled</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bad at</vocabulary>!

Think of someone holding out their hand. This is average. Things rated below the hand are things you're bad at. Things rated <kanji>above</kanji> the <kanji>hand</kanji> are things you're <vocabulary>good at</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

By itself, 文 can also just mean <vocabulary>sentence</vocabulary>, especially in grammatical contexts.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Take note that this word means both "sun" and "day," though. Why? because the sun takes a day to go around and come back!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The kanji for "moon" and "month" are the same, probably because a moon cycle takes approximately a month to occur. So, what is the tenth moon cycle of the year? That would be the awesome month <vocabulary>October</vocabulary>!

Since the kanji 月 mean both moon and month (because a moon cycle is about a month, presumably), what is the number one month? In English we have an actual name for it, and that name is <vocabulary>January</vocabulary>.

The kanji 月 means both month and moon (because moon cycles take about a month, presumably). So, what is the number two month? It's not January... it's not March... it's <vocabulary>February</vocabulary>!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
This vocab is made from a single kanji, which means it shares the same meaning as the parent kanji: <vocabulary>fire</vocabulary>.
A fire mountain is probably what you think it is: A <vocabulary>volcano</vocabulary>.
This vocab made up of a single kanji shares its meaning with said single kanji. That meaning is <vocabulary>dog</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>child</kanji> <kanji>dog</kanji> is a <vocabulary>puppy</vocabulary>!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>king</kanji>'s <kanji>child</kanji> is the <vocabulary>prince</vocabulary>. Someday he'll be the 王, if he's lucky, but right now he's just the king's child, a.k.a. the prince!

If you prefer some grammatical details, you can try to remember that when a word consists of two kanji, sometimes the first kanji has a possessive relation to the second. In this case, 王 possesses 子, making it the king's child. Historically, male children had priority in royal succession, so I guess that's why this word means "prince."

The woman king is the queen. You know this because the woman who comes before the king must be the queen. Imagine this woman in front, leading the king around. Only a queen could do that! For a more technical explanation, just remember that when a word consists of two kanji characters, the first kanji often modifies the second. In this case, 女 modifies 王, making it the woman king, a.k.a. the queen!

The king's woman (or girl) is the princess. You know she's the princess because she comes after the king — she's just his daughter and doesn't have as much power. Imagine the king with a young woman following after him. Must be the princess! If you prefer some grammatical details, you can try to remember that when a word consists of two kanji, sometimes the first kanji has a possessive relation to the second. In this case, 王 possesses 女, making it the king's girl (almost like "daddy's girl"). In other words, the princess!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "exit," so what is the verb form of that? It's <vocabulary>to exit</vocabulary>.
The mouth you exit out of is just a doorway (I hope), but an easier way to describe this word or concept is to call it an <vocabulary>exit</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
This vocab word has the same meaning as its parent kanji (single alone kanji usually do that!), meaning it means <vocabulary>four</vocabulary>.

月 in Japanese means "moon" but it also means "month." Why? Probably because the moon takes about a month to get through its cycles. So, what's the fourth moon of the year? Here's a hint, it's the same as the fourth month of the year: <vocabulary>April</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This vocab word is exactly the same as its parent kanji, including its meaning as well: <vocabulary>book</vocabulary>. It doesn't have those other meanings though, when it's just 本 alone, it's just a book.

Remember the secondary meaning of 本 being "origin"? That technically makes this <kanji>sun</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji>. Does that sound familiar? Japan is known as the "land of the rising sun", which is why this means <vocabulary>Japan</vocabulary>!

Ending with an い tells you that this word is an い-adjective. So since you know that the kanji <kanji>正</kanji> means "<kanji>correct</kanji>," what is the adjective version of that word? Well, it's also <vocabulary>correct</vocabulary>.

This word is made up of a kanji with some hiragana attached, ending in an う sound. That means this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "correct," so what is the verb form of that? It would be <vocabulary>to correct</vocabulary>.

As a single kanji vocab on its own, you know this vocab word has the same meaning as its parent kanji: <vocabulary>ball</vocabulary>.

玉 can be used for round objects traditionally recognized in Japanese culture, like beads, marbles, pearls, snowballs, and pachinko balls. For balls used in sports, people typically use the katakana word ボール.

ねぎ means "onion" in Japanese. But, there are different kinds of onions, right? This happens to be a "ball onion," which is just one of those round ones, like a Walla Walla Sweet <vocabulary>Onion</vocabulary>. Do you know?

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Just keep in mind that compared to 田んぼ, which you learned earlier, this word is more formal and less colloquial.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
This word uses <kanji>white</kanji> and <kanji>person</kanji> ... put those together and you have a <vocabulary>white person</vocabulary>, aka a <vocabulary>caucasian</vocabulary> person.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
What is an <kanji>eye</kanji> <kanji>ball</kanji>? Oh wait, that's easy. It's an <vocabulary>eyeball</vocabulary>!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means "stand" so what is the verb version of that? It's <vocabulary>to stand</vocabulary>.
<vocabulary>Second day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day two</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this combination of kanji, the meaning of the word makes a lot of sense!
<kanji>Person</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji>, why, that's more than one person. It's <vocabulary>people</vocabulary>!
This word has two different meanings. <vocabulary>One day</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>first day</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, those meanings make a lot of sense.
<vocabulary>Seventh day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day seven</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
<vocabulary>Third day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day three</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
<vocabulary>Ninth day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day nine</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
<vocabulary>Eighth day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day eight</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.
<vocabulary>Tenth day</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>day ten</vocabulary>. No matter how you look at this word, it makes a lot of sense.

This words is all about doing something in a big way. Particle に on the end tells us its an adverb, meaning that it describes how an action is carried out. It can mean very, a lot of, or greatly, depending on the context.
If you're in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of a bunch of <kanji>water</kanji>, then you're most likely <vocabulary>underwater</vocabulary>.
Put <kanji>left</kanji> and <kanji>right</kanji> together and you end up with <vocabulary>left and right</vocabulary>! Just make sure you say them in the right order!

<kanji>Enter</kanji> something with all your <kanji>strength</kanji> and you will look down to see that what you're doing is <vocabulary>input</vocabulary>ting data. You're inputting it right now! Into this site! The answers you <vocabulary>enter</vocabulary> into WaniKani with all your strength can be said with this word. Wow. Full circle already, and you're only on level 2. Look at you go!

You know that the kanji 田 means <kanji>rice paddy</kanji>, so it should be easy to work out that this word also means <vocabulary>rice paddy</vocabulary>.

田んぼ is a common way to say "rice paddy," especially in casual conversation. You can tell because if you ever came across a ju<reading>mbo</reading> (んぼ) rice paddy, you'd probably say something like, "Whoa, that's one jumbo 田んぼ!" When a 田んぼ is that jumbo, the surprise makes your speech naturally more relaxed and informal.
